posts.com:
Diet & Body Re-composition

Initial Body Fat and Body Composition Changes

General Philosophies of Muscle Mass Gain

Sample Diets
Read the above articles, and decide whether you need to bulk (add muscle), cut (lose fat), or maintain.

Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) in calories

Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories
Protein: 1+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories
Protein: 1.5+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

>works the entire body, especially good for shoulders

>can adjust your technique to go heavier on arms or legs to mitigate fatigue and continue pushing longer
>unlimited resistance - can go light or heavy, determined completely by the level of force you apply
>can sync strokes and distance metrics to rowing apps to allow you to row through norweigan channels, venice canals, out on the pacific ocean, etc.
bros... posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Learning the hard way edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For Enthusiastic eaters who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Previous thread: >>69848013

>i work part time about 20-25 hours and study and lift in the time im not working
Anon for what it's worth coming from somebody else at the other end of an anime imageboard, it sounds like you are in a very good station in life. You're clearly pursuing some sort of existential goal even if you are not entirely certain what it is and that's saying a lot for people raised in this society today.
Speaking from the perspective of someone who has depression and has been suffering from it since they were roughly 13, it's fine to have absolutely shit periods of time where you feel you're just going "through the motions" because in reality you probably are. It's unlikely you or I will ever be fully "free" from depression in this lifetime, it's important to reflect that this is, as you said, an episode. Which means there is an end to it. Then you'll have a "meh" mediocre period. Then maybe another bad period. Then meh, then good for a while etc. etc. on the carousel of life
Also - again for what it's worth - the numbers you said are really damn good in my eyes. Hell I only recently started DEADLIFTING 142kg for reps, your squats sound unobtainable for me.
Chin up, you are never completely isolated in your feelings.

You could try combining 500mg DLPA with 600mg St Johns wort. Both can be ordered on amazon. Just make sure you dont combine them with other antidepressants because then you’d risk getting serotonin syndrome.

posts.com:
>>69856687
You're depressed due to unhealed psychological trauma, most often from childhood experiences. The depressive episodes flare up as your neurons replay patterns that caused you negative emotion in the past.

You can fix this by handlihrng the undigested ball of trauma in your subconscious through introspection and thought, guided meditation or therapy. I did this personally through active introspection and writing after studying Dr Alok Kanojia's youtube series on these undigested emotions, called 'samscara' in the Eastern Sanskrit/Buddhist tradition.

I have not had a depressive episode in more than four years, and point to this as the number one causative factor, as medication, diet, exercise and social/financial/physical achievements did not suffice.

Unless you do the work to confront your inner, hidden traumas, you will continue to suffer until you die.

Dr. Kanojia (Dr. K)'s youtube channel is HealthyGamerGG, as he focuses on the mental health of young people avoiding their trauma through escapism like video game addiction. I HEAVILY recommend you watch at least one video if you want to help yourself, or bookmark/subscribe for when your episode passes and you have more motivation. Pick whichever title you feel like adapts to your situation, although I learned the most from his interviews with streamers I didn't know or care about. Learning about them and seeing how their issues presented and mirrored my own made me less judgemental and more empathetic, as well as helped me confront and fix my own issues.

I cannot descibe to you the joy and comfort in knowing that depression will not swoop in from the heavens to unman me, rob me of motivation and progression towards my goals, and damage my life's work and relationships. This is the most important thing I ever did for myself.

"Yes I may not be the most attractive, but I shouldn't disregard my hygiene and personality because of that"

"Yes I may not be the most talented, but I should still aim to be better at this subject that I enjoy, after all being good at something allows you to appreciate it more"

posts.com:
>>69859699

I have pinned quads basically exclusively (occasionally doing vent glute and trying out other spots when I was using ungodly amounts of oil weekly and needed to find places to put it) and never had an issue.

How to never fuck up quad pinning:
-Pin with the leg slightly bent. Fully extended makes the quad more relaxed but sucks ass after. A middle ground between extension/contracted states is ideal. My knee is close to a 90 degree angle when I pin, so its EZPZ to do sitting down.
-Never ever perform knee flexion with the needle inside of you.
-Actually pin the correct area. Proper quad IM injections are in the lateralis, so if sitting down with the knee at 90 degrees, the syringe is parallel to the floor entering the side of the leg. Put your middle finger in the little pocket on the side of your kneecap and extend your thumb out as far up the side of your leg as you can, where your thumb lands is right around where ideal quad IM location is.
-This one is just me, but stick the needle in slowly. You should feel a sting upon entry (duh) but there shouldn't be any particular pain as the needle drives in. If it suddenly starts to sting, you're hitting a vein or nerve. If it's near the surface, up to you to work through it or not. If it's close to the bottom of the needle, if you decide to just keep going ahead with the pin, tren cough is absolutely gonna say hello to you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69861102

"Too high" cruise dosage is a dose your body is unable to regulate your vitals like blood pressure and cholesterol on. A lot of guys do a "sports TRT" dosage which is 250mg a week. Fine for a young person, but an older guy at that dose might struggle to keep his bloodwork within healthy ranges.

So yeah. There's no dose that works for everyone and there's nothing wrong with a higher dose provided your body can still effectively manage it. Envision cruises as recovery periods. Your bloodwork gets fucked while blasting, so you cruise to reset everything to healthy levels. If your cruise dose is too high, that process doesn't occur, so the cruise is pointless and you're essentially still blasting.

tldr
1)Hormones are very powerful and change your body composition. Not only do they effect the partitioning of nutrients, but how hungry you are, how much you move around, etc
2)
insulin +muscle +fat
testosterone +muscle -fat
cortisol -muscle +fat
hgh +muscle -fat
3) It isn't the mere presence of these hormones , but it needs to be a high amount and be consistent. If you get a lot of cortisol for a couple weeks because of job stress, it probably won't matter, but if it's all year you might get more fat from it.
4)Exercise is probably the best thing you can do without drugs. Meditation,stretching, slow breathing, yoga etc can reduce cortisol. Fasting increases your insulin resistance, meaning your body gives you less insulin in response. All of this would need to be done consistently for a long time to really make a difference though.

>T
BMBPMk1-BtMLaAP-BMBPMk2-BDT BtM W2D1
>F
Why yes, I enjoy having my head kicked in by Jam Wambler. Even on the "easy" week 2 I really had to summon intestinal fortitude to get through this workout.

Tried a 10 minute EMOM doing chins and dips to get going. This was quite a good idea. It certainly got me warm.

Squat: 85kg x5 102.5kg x5 115kg 5x5. Superset the 5x5 with chins and dips and pullaparts. Had to switch over to assisted chins. The squats weren't too bad. The high bar position has really helped eliminate some of the trap soreness from Friday's session.

Log clean and press 40kg x5 45kg x5 50kg x5 40kg x7. This is possibly the most taxing movement I've done. Doesn't help that my upper back remains ruined from Friday... Pretty happy with the way the top set moved.

Finished off the chins after this. I. FUCKING. HATE. CHINS.. I'm a 40 year old, 94kg fat lad. Chin ups should be illegal for people like me.

videos: https://imgur.com/a/OfjMLWm

Dips though, I like them despite getting a bit of a painful stretch across the sternum. Not enough to stop me, I also got a tiddy pump.

Other news: binged to the end of the first tranche of Physical:100 episodes last night. That cliffhanger though. I can safely say I was rooting hard for the underdogs in that challenge, which looked brutal as fuck.

Happy Sunday. Stay runny plg. Diarrhea Boy Out.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)

- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk

posts.com: If you’re a beginner runner should you even worry about doing certain things to improve time or just keep running for a while?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69831582
>If you’re a beginner runner should you even worry about doing certain things to improve time or just keep running for a while?

Couch to 5k is designed for the beginner runner. It gets you gradually into the swing of things. The "to 5k" part is mostly to motivate people with a goal.

But if you don't want to follow any kind of plan, you can spend a month or so going for runs with little mind for distance or pace (though definitely pay attention if you feel pain) and once you're comfortable you can start training with a little more focus on your own specific goals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69828449
Just get your squat to 1x-1.5x bodyweight, diddle 1.5-2.0x bodyweight, OHP 0.5x-0.75x bodyweight for a solid base.
From this point on, strength in the powershitting movements aren't that important. You should focus on power and stability on one leg.
Do plyometric drills 1.5x/week to focus on power generation. (In the running motion, you are on one leg trying to generate force for like 0.33 seconds, this is very important)
For strength, try to mix in some one-legged movements. walking lunges are probably goat, also one-legged diddle, squat.
A good test for strength/stability on one leg is to see how many single-leg bodyweight calf-raises you can do.

I bought a quality one, because I run ultras every once in a while and didn't regret the purchase, because it's still going strong. Also back then tail lights weren't as much of a thing, so I got a cheap one and attached it to the straps.
That said, chest lamps have their own advantage for runners, as you want the floor right in fron of you illuminated and a light shining down in a steep angle from your forehead can be annoying, especially in damp weather and with glasses. Also from a traffic perspective, they are shining ahead at all time and not where your head turns, so you are slightly better visible. Annoying though, when you want to check noises around you. My gf uses the run light 250, from decathlong, but there are cheaper versions around.
Also note that USB charge and disposable batteries both have their (dis)advantages.

>>69861895
Yoga is a broader term in Sanskrit.

How it has come to be in English, and the way it is being used in this thread, it means exercises. Not even just stretching, exercises.

Many of these exercises overlap with other culture's practices. Many of these exercises are used widely in the medical field, and are at use normally at your local cricket or football club for warm ups.

These are known as hathayoga exercises. Some of these exercises provide less targeted strength building than lifting, others raise flexibility. There are exercises which increase grace and efficiency of movement, and exercises which train the brain to visualize or task manage better. These latter few categories can tend to overlap more with the other more spiritual branches of yoga, but it's all connected really.

At the end of the day, if you sit down and observe what yoga is beyond the veil of the wild Christian imagination, you would be quite hard tried to stop doing yoga. It's actually a complex system of schooling for numerous aspects of life.

So in short, yes it's bases, but not to the point where it should be overstated. Only in the sense that breaking down the aspects of your existence into parts and working to improve them is a good idea, and you're probably just doing that shit anyway.

I'm doing a 700 cal deficit so looking at maybe 5-8 months to reach my goal weight. I have a weight bench (pic related) with an olympic barbell as well as some adjustable dumbbells and a treadmill

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69834422
What you're referring to is "recomp" which is putting on muscle without gaining or losing fat. While it's technically possible to go from obese to lean this way, it's very, very, very slow. You'd lose the fat in a quarter of the time if you just did a traditional cut.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69834487
I don't get way is more efficient to cut and then to bulk rather than recomping.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69834548
Recomp means you are not at a caloric deficit, so your body isn't going to burn its fat reserves for energy (You can build muscle slowly this way as your body will use the protein it eats for protein synthesis). If you want to lose bodyfat, the fastest way to do that is to get your body to tap into those reserves for energy as a result of a deficit instead of chipping tiny pieces off while at basically no deficit.

Retard speak: Recomping won't burn fat reserves the way a deficit will.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69834422
>bodybuilders are overweight or even obese based on their bmi, even though their bf%
because bmi doesn't take into account muscle or fat, just what the scale says. it's a good gauge for normal people, but it's not accurate for people with muscle mass

Should that .82 protein per lb based off of your current weight or your goal weight?
Im 193lbs right now, aiming for 175lbs

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69835291
You base it off your current weight and bodyfat%. So for example: if you're 23% bodyfat, you'd subtract that from your total weight. In this scenario 23% of 193 is 44 lbs, so you'd subtract that from 193 to get 149. Then you multiply 149 by 0.82 to get the amount of protein you need, 122 in this example.

hope that helps!

>>69839757
This is how I view RPE/RIR. Fresh in a new periodization, I base it off my 1RM=RPE10/RIR0. Say the workout asked for 5 reps @ RPE8/RIR2 - Using a "find your 1rm chart" or my own experience, I know what weights I can do for 7 reps before I hit failure and that is my working weight for that set of 5.

Personally, I prefer using percentages for my blocks (WK1 1RM, WK2 70%, WK3 75%..). It's how I initially learned how to lift and I'm pretty set un my ways. However, I do prefer the occasional RPE flexibility: What is hard for me at this level TODAY? Compared to when I last did the exercise, I could come in feeling like a champ, and something that was an I before now feels like a 6. Or the opposite; I had shit sleep or I'm sore, so the effort will still be there, but the weight may not be, so I won't feel bad about not hitting my targeted percentages for that day.

I don't know if my ranting made sense, or was any way helpful, but enjoy a Billy on me.

posts.com:
>>69839757
Ignore the retards. Congrats man, you've logically deduced the most basic thing about fitness that makes 0 sense but people keep trying to shill it to confuse you and sell you their programs and solutions. RIR and RPE and all that shit is useless because you literally are incapable of knowing how many you could have gotten without actually reaching failure. The only thing you can really know about where your RPE is at is if you're at either 0 (rest) or 10 (failure). Anything between those two is a complete mystery and literally cannot be used to make a basis for a consistent approach with training.

Good thing you don't need that shit anyway. Just hit failure. Once is enough. Anywhere between 5-35 reps until you fail. Approach it very slowly with 5 seconds up, 5 seconds down, and short pauses at the bottom and the top. Fail within 60-90 seconds of beginning the lift. Only use enough weight to get to failure within that timeframe. Only add more when your times start to go above that range. One set, per session per muscle group, twice per week maximum unless you roid.

Train to failure, rest enough to recover, rest even more to grow.

Do this and you will get the same fucking results as doing 5-10 sets and you will have 0 risk of overtraining or undertraining. Everything else is either a scam or under/misinformed people trying to help even though they don't know what they're doing and they are just parroting someone else that also does not know what they are doing. You'll save a shitload of time and never be confused if you do this. It's safer since you're going slow and using lighter weights as a result and is also consistent. There's literally no reason to do anything else, unless you just like training another way. If you just want results and don't want any of the fitness industry horseshit, just do this.

Sources: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1iQ-OGWrY6qvdjtSq4aEcATp1nwf743suWZR9VpwfHw0/edit?usp=sharing

If you keep doing the same thing every day you will not gain muscle. You will simply maintain your existing muscle. If you want to gain muscle, you have to push yourself by doing exercises harder.

You couldn't if you tried you dyel. Nobody accidentally fucks around and gains an impressive physique by accident. Push hard when you want to get bigger and just keep doing the same thing over and over if you want to maintain. If you don't take it seriously and actually attempt to gain muscle, you probably never will

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69861405
>don't usually go to failure
Take each exercise to failure on the last set of every exercise that you do. The other sets you can continue to do as normal if you want, but hit failure at least once on every exercise every session. You might not be going hard enough to stimulate growth and there's no real way to know for sure unless you hit failure. If you're worried about being in a weird position and failing, like with the pike for example, you can do that motion until you are getting close and then superset it with something a lot safer like an overhead press with something in the nearby vicinity that is relatively light like some books or something. I would strongly advise getting at least some cheap light dumbbells. They help tremendously.

>I work out every other day
That's very much not necessary and will actively impede your progress. That's 3-4 times a week. Assuming you don't roid then you'll need time to recover. If you start going to failure and really sending it when you work out, you can be 100% sure that you're going to grow after that so long as you properly rest and diet. There is no difference in the amount of gains from exercising 1 time per week vs 2 times per week vs 3 times per week. The only thing that you can possibly do by doing more than once or twice a week is accidentally overtrain. You really can't fuck up with over resting unless you just stop completely for 3 weeks.

Your diet doesn't sound too bad at all, but if you are not eating the same thing every day then you don't know for sure if you're hitting protein and calorie goals. Either switch to eating the same thing every day or begin logging your meals as you eat them to be certain you're doing it right. It's a shame to do all of this hard work and get literally nothing from it when all you have to do is eat another 40 grams of protein or something.

Increase intensity to force growth. Decrease frequency to allow recovery. Get serious on diet tracking

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69861559
Once or twice a week is perfectly acceptable. Pretty much everyone can consistently make gains with this frequency. You may also want to regularly take 10 days off every 6-8 weeks. Training breaks can help break plateaus if you experience them. Also, pay attention to how you feel when you begin a session. If you still feel like total dogshit from last time, you should not do a session on that day. It is very hard to fuck up over-resting. You essentially just have to give up lifting to fuck up with over-resting. It takes 3 weeks for atrophy to start. Your gains will not disappear so long as you consistently exercise. It's far more likely that you will overtrain than over-rest

I'm assuming that you're not ridiculously jacked, but even if you were, 40s should work pretty well. Just make sure to go very very close to failure on your bodyweight exercises to fatigue the muscle as much as possible. Go as hard/far as you feel safe with and then switch to the dumbbells to safely finish the job. So long as you're very close to failure, 40 lbs dumbbells will feel very heavy no matter what you're doing with them. Depending on how close you are, even 10s or 20s can feel really heavy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69861787
The issue with what you're doing now is that you aren't sure whether or not your training is working. By going to failure at least once per session you can be certain that it is providing enough of an aggressive stimulus to promote muscle growth. You can't go any harder than absolute failure. There's nothing more to give. Going to failure will make you sore and do more damage than simply doing light to medium sets until you've hit an arbitrary number, but you can be sure you're going to grow from it. When you hit failure you have to go balls to the wall and really send it. If you do this, the extra rest days will make sense.

For calories, set however many calories you want/think you need. Eat that same amount of calories per day and check the scale consistently. If you see the scale going up or down, then you know it's working. Counting calories is not as accurate as it would seem. Food companies can fudge any of those numbers by up to 15% up or down, so you need to rely on a more reliable method such as a scale. Track progress over weeks and not days though.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69862259
Your TDEE is going to change dramatically when you start lifting. Lifting weights increases your muscle size (increasing basal metabolic rate) and the process is highly anabolic (which will increase your TDEE). So, be prepared for it to change a lot.

Do not bulk/gain excess fat. Honestly, I think you're going to have to figure this one out for yourself. How much your TDEE changes depends entirely on how much you lift, what you lift (compounds are more effective than isolation exercises) and with what intensity.

I would just start with aiming for 170 grams of protein and then seeing what feels reasonable from there. 2200 is probably a good guess but, again, it will depend on a lot of variables.

posts.com:
>>69864332
I'm from Denmark actually. Our water quality is high but here on Sjælland it's so hard it's borderline hazardous, so my gf got a Brita to avoid having to descale her tea kettle every other day. It did great for that but our house is from the 1800s and the pipes are probably not good. There's a lot of sediment in our water that the Brita didn't filter out for some reason. In my exasperation I got that RO system but I should have probably done a bit more research beforehand.
For one, it's one of their passive systems which means its efficiency is dependent on your house water pressure. Cold water also makes it less efficient. You can make it wildly more efficient by buying a permeate pump, which they also sell. Second: the tank is not just a tank but a special air cushioned shell that provides the pressure, meaning it can break. Depending on your use it might be better to invest in a pump-driven system up front. The downside to a pumped system is that it needs power to give you water and the RO membranes are a larger and much more expensive size.
I was going for cheap at the time. It's a really good system mind you and I'm very happy with it. The tank even came in handy when there was an unexpected water shutoff a few months ago.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69864399
Also, I linked to 6 stage system with the remineralizer. They're kind of a scam. They don't actually add any significant amount of minerals back into the water but they do prevent the water from reacting with CO2 in the air making it more acidic the longer it's exposed, which improves the flavor somewhat. The slightly cheaper 5-stage systems are more than enough.

>>69840650
Sounds like what you need is a good plyometric workout. You can google some stuff but here’s what I would start with.

4 sets of weighted clap pushups x failure (really helps your jab and cross be more explosive)
4 sets weighted jump squats x failure (good for explosive foot work)
3 rounds (2-3 minutes) of weighted foot work/shadow boxing drills. You can use a weight vest/dumbbells or both.
3 sets of pull ups x failure. This is the only one that’s not really a plyometric but it will help balance out the rest of your physique.

May not sound like much but if this is a supplemental workout it should improve your performance, speed, and power. You can progressively overload all of these as well. Just don’t sacrifice form for more weight.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
6 foot,186ib dyel reporting in. I spent 2 months fucking around with unweighted calisthenics and occasionally doing some biceps curls with 15ib dumbbells. Realized I had made zero gains, so I've been lifting actual weights and slowly creating a meme routine based on heavy volume since early December. I start by doing 10 sets of an exercise (40-60 second rest period between sets), and switch to 8 sets with an increased number of reps before rotating back to 10 sets. Gains are starting to come fast and my level of endurance continuously surprises me. I think doing low intensity cardio before every workout has really helped. I will begin cutting down to 170 pounds when summer begins and hopefully at that weight my lower abs and obliques will be showing. And yes, my gains would probably be much faster if I did SS or some other normie shit, but it wouldn't be nearly as much fun. Working out entirely from home btw.

Sorry for the blog post.

>>69861468
A scientifically-supported resistance training routine would typically involve the following components:

Warm-up: Before starting any strength training exercises, it's important to warm up to reduce the risk of injury. A 5-10 minute warm-up consisting of dynamic stretching and light cardio is recommended.

Exercise Selection: Choose exercises that target multiple muscle groups and that promote functional movement patterns, such as squats, deadlifts, bench press, pull-ups, and rows.

Repetitions and Sets: Aim for 3-5 sets of each exercise, with 8-12 repetitions per set. This repetition range will allow you to effectively stimulate muscle growth (hypertrophy) and increase strength.

Load: Gradually increase the weight used for each exercise as you get stronger. The weight should be heavy enough that you struggle to complete the last few reps of each set.

Rest: Allow for adequate rest between sets, about 2-3 minutes, to allow your muscles to recover and perform optimally in the next set.

Progression: Gradually increase the difficulty of the exercises over time. This can be achieved by increasing weight, reps, or sets, or by adding more challenging exercises.

Variety: Regularly switch up the exercises you perform, to prevent boredom and to challenge your muscles in different ways.

Frequency: Aim to perform resistance training 2-3 times per week, allowing at least 48 hours of recovery between sessions.

Recovery: In addition to adequate rest between sets, it's important to include active recovery in your routine, such as stretching, foam rolling, and massages, to help speed up the recovery process.

It is important to consult a fitness professional or medical professional before starting a new exercise routine to ensure that it is safe and appropriate for you.

Monday: Upper Body

Eggs. 12+ per day. Don't get that vegetarian fed crap. Get eggs chickens that are actually allowed to run around a field and pick at bugs and small animals in addition to their feed. If you have the space for it, I would recommend getting your own. You can feed them leftovers too.

Steak from grass fed cattle. Make sure to eat the liver (best source of vitamins on the planet), 1 lb per month. Ask the butcher to cut it int 2-4 oz pieces and eat them throughout the month.
Chicken is great if you eat the liver too. Make sure they're fed the same quality you expect of the chickens you get your eggs from.

Starchy vegetables like carrots and legumes like potatoes (superior carbs to any grains). Tomatoes. If you grow a tomato plant or two, you'll have more tomatoes than you know what to do with.
Peppers of many varieties.
Butter and Cheese from Grass fed cattle. If you can get butter and cheese made from raw milk, that's even better.

For oils, only ghee, Avacado oil, and olive oil. Make sure that you get the real stuff and not the adulterated imitations or fakes you may commonly see. You can look up ways to distinguish between the real thing and fakes.

All of this should be organic as well. Non-organic foods are generally unhealthy.

>>69862263
There was a huge compilation of meta-analyses that I read and wish I saved that showed no real benefits above 0.7g of protein per pound of bodyweight per day for bodybuilding and strength training. It's the same one that gave people the suggestion to eat 25g+ of protein 5-6 times per day with especially large men needing 40g+ per meal.
Also reading the studies they used made me realize that protein needs don't change past baseline. When noobs were used the optimal protein was near 0.75g per pound, but after 2 years of lifting, it dropped to 0.6g-0.65g per pound. Assuming stable fat mass and tracking estimated LBM gains the amount of protein you'd need to make optimal gains doesn't change much from baseline at all. If you need 150g on day one you'll still need 150g on day one thousand

>>69849333
Get yourself a prescription for generic Naltrexone. Any doctor can write you one, even an online teledoc.

Naltrexone blocks the effects of alcohol on your brain. It won't keep you from getting physically drunk, but it knocks out the euphoric aspects that causes people to lose control of their drinking.

98% of managing alcohol abuse is having the willpower to stay away and managing your impulses. But having some Naltrexone as an "emergency brake" is really helpful.

>>69856305
It's called the "elderly open" from the book Day Bang by RooshV. He is now an Orthodox Christian and deleted his material from the internet, but you can probably still find it somewhere. It's actually very effective.

The book sounds like a pickup artist manual (and I guess it is) but the "elderly open" is basically just a simple conversational framework that makes it easy to meet women in a public place. It's not a way to trick or magically seduce them.

This is specifically for places like a coffee shop or library where women generally don't want to be hit on by a random guy. It is important to keep the conversation NON flirty; you're just a nice guy who is striking up a chat.

>step 1: ask an innocuous question
This can literally be about the kind of pen she's using, it can be about the best cup of coffee nearby, it can be anything that is not personal.
>"Excuse me, do you happen to know where I can get a good cup of coffee near here?"
>step 2: ask more clarifying questions
"Oh, Cafe Anon? Do you know if they do cold brew? Yeah haha when it's sunny out I can only drink iced coffee. Do you know if it's proper cold brew? Not just some ice cubes dropped in hot coffee, right?"

>which diet is best for weight loss
No one can answer this, no one knows the answer, there probably is no answer. Some will say keto, others vegan, carnivore, fasting, cabbage soup. There are all these different so-called diets out there and the reality is they can all work.

What are you defining as "weight loss"? The term weight loss is often confused with the term fat loss. So you can lose 50lbs and still look flabby, is that ok with you? Or do you really mean "fat loss" which will result in having a tighter more muscular look?

Next, what are you defining as "best"? Do you mean fastest, cheapest, most sustainable, most nutritionally complete? If you mean fastest, my answer is simply eating nothing.

I can't tell you the "best" diet for weight loss, I will also make the assumption you have confused weight loss with fat loss. My opinion is that following these steps will result in a variable, sustainable diet that CAN result in a leaner more muscular body if combined with strength training:
1. Eat 1g/lb in protein
2. Double your bodyweight (lbs) and multiply it by 0.35, this is how many grams of carbs a day, do the same but multiply by 0.15, this is how many grams of fat per day.
3. Figure out an easy to follow diet that reaches roughly these numbers that you can eat every day: avoid ultra-processed foods, most vegetables have so little macros they should be eaten without affecting your results negatively while providing micronutrients.
4. To encourage fat loss, lower your carbs by 10, your fat by 5 and your protein by 5
5. After two weeks, if no progress, lower the numbers again.

Getting that much protein can be hard, best sources: turkey, chicken breast, eggs, egg white, edamame beans, tofu, skyr or low fat yoghurt, canned fish. The diet is compatible with everything except keto and carnivore.

>>69862919
As I understand it "seed oils" are essentially industrial waste products that get heavily processed to be edible. stuff like walnut oil isnt even even all bad, but it oxidize rapidly when exposed to oxygen. Anything you can buy in the store will already have turned bad. This is because fatty acids like omega 3 (which these seeds end up completely full of) are oxidents. Omega 6 are anti-oxidents, which is why they're advertised as being healthy for you. Oxidents cause inflamation in the body which in turn can cause a host of issues, ranging from little pains and aches to feeling chronically fatigued etc.
Stick with butter, coconut oil and olive oil just to be sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69862209
Okay so I have absolutely shit joints. I get injuries a lot if I'm not careful because I pushed myself to get overtraining syndrome and you can't 100% recover from it. I don't get tendon and ligament injures much anymore with these 3 types of lifts and 2 considerations in my routine
>high rep, high frequency lifting
Tendons and ligaments have no blood supply so you have to move them to get nutrients in them. More than half of my sets are high rep (10-15 being the lowest in that category) and I hit any given muscle 3+ times per week now in some way
>heavy eccentrics
Single most important concept that healed my tricep tendonopathy. Tendons when placed under very heavy loads grow much quicker than people think. The issue is that they don't handle the concentric as well as the eccentric with those heavy loads. Its best to remove or limit the concentric. An example would be if you had patellar tendon issues you could fix it by bringing a leg extension up with two legs and lowering it with one with a very heavy load for 3x8 three times per week. You can use that for any tendon and it'll work
>isometric loading
When old school strongmen got on the autopsy table doctors were always amazed at how thick and strong their bones and ligaments were. They trained them by doing overcoming isometrics with the joints straightened. Ligaments are strongest in their most shortened position and they'd do things like hold cars in a leg press position or have someone put 2000+ pounds on their backs. You don't have to go that extreme but the concept applies to any joint if you have fucky ligaments
>no egolifting
Slow down your tempo a little and don't ever allow touch and go stuff or a lot of body english to the point where its hard to control the weight. A little cheating is fine but relying on it to lift the weights for you is going to fuck your joints
>no lift is mandatory
If a lift is putting pressure on your joints, drop that lift. Don't EVER force it or you'll get injured
